defs.docs:
This crate provides a smattering of safe routines for parts of winapi. The
primary purpose of this crate is to serve as a dumping ground for various
utility functions that make interactions with winapi safe. This permits the
centralization of `unsafe` when dealing with Windows APIs, and thus makes it
easier to audit.

attributes.value:
*
This crate provides a smattering of safe routines for parts of winapi. The
primary purpose of this crate is to serve as a dumping ground for various
utility functions that make interactions with winapi safe. This permits the
centralization of `unsafe` when dealing with Windows APIs, and thus makes it
easier to audit.

A key abstraction in this crate is the combination of the
[`Handle`](struct.Handle.html)
and
[`HandleRef`](struct.HandleRef.html)
types. Both represent a valid Windows handle to an I/O-like object, where
`Handle` is owned (the resource is closed when the handle is dropped) and
`HandleRef` is borrowed (the resource is not closed when the handle is
dropped). Many of the routines in this crate work on handles and accept
anything that can be safely converted into a `HandleRef`. This includes
standard library types such as `File`, `Stdin`, `Stdout` and `Stderr`.

Note that this crate is completely empty on non-Windows platforms.
*/

defs.name: console
defs.docs: Safe routines for dealing with the Windows console.

attributes.value: / Safe routines for dealing with the Windows console.
cfg(windows)

defs.name: screen_buffer_info
defs.docs: Query the given handle for information about the console's screen buffer.

attributes.value: / Query the given handle for information about the console's screen buffer.
/ The given handle should represent a console. Otherwise, an error is
/ returned.
/ This corresponds to calling [`GetConsoleScreenBufferInfo`].
/ [`GetConsoleScreenBufferInfo`]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/console/getconsolescreenbufferinfo

defs.name: set_text_attributes
defs.value: pub fn set_text_attributes<H: AsHandleRef>(H, u16) -> io::Result<()>
defs.docs: Set the text attributes of the console represented by the given handle.

attributes.value: / Set the text attributes of the console represented by the given handle.
/ This corresponds to calling [`SetConsoleTextAttribute`].
/ [`SetConsoleTextAttribute`]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/console/setconsoletextattribute

defs.name: mode
defs.docs: Query the mode of the console represented by the given handle.

attributes.value: / Query the mode of the console represented by the given handle.
/ This corresponds to calling [`GetConsoleMode`], which describes the return
/ value.
/ [`GetConsoleMode`]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/console/getconsolemode

defs.name: set_mode
defs.value: pub fn set_mode<H: AsHandleRef>(H, u32) -> io::Result<()>
defs.docs: Set the mode of the console represented by the given handle.

attributes.value: / Set the mode of the console represented by the given handle.
/ This corresponds to calling [`SetConsoleMode`], which describes the format

/ [`SetConsoleMode`]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/console/setconsolemode

defs.name: ScreenBufferInfo
defs.docs:
Represents console screen buffer information such as size, cursor position
 and styling attributes.

attributes.value: / Represents console screen buffer information such as size, cursor position
/ and styling attributes.
/ This wraps a [`CONSOLE_SCREEN_BUFFER_INFO`].
/ [`CONSOLE_SCREEN_BUFFER_INFO`]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/console/console-screen-buffer-info-str

defs.docs:
Returns the size of the console screen buffer, in character columns and
 rows.

attributes.value: / Returns the size of the console screen buffer, in character columns and
/ rows.
/ This corresponds to `dwSize`.

defs.name: cursor_position
defs.docs:
Returns the position of the cursor in terms of column and row
 coordinates of the console screen buffer.

attributes.value: / Returns the position of the cursor in terms of column and row
/ coordinates of the console screen buffer.
/ This corresponds to `dwCursorPosition`.

defs.name: attributes
defs.docs: Returns the character attributes associated with this console.

attributes.value: / Returns the character attributes associated with this console.
/ This corresponds to `wAttributes`.
/ See [`char info`] for more details.
/ [`char info`]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/console/char-info-str

defs.name: max_window_size
defs.docs:
Returns the maximum size of the console window, in character columns
 and rows, given the current screen buffer size and font and the screen
 size.

attributes.value: / Returns the maximum size of the console window, in character columns
/ and rows, given the current screen buffer size and font and the screen
/ size.

defs.name: window_rect
defs.docs:
Returns the console screen buffer coordinates of the upper-left and
 lower-right corners of the display window.

attributes.value: / Returns the console screen buffer coordinates of the upper-left and
/ lower-right corners of the display window.
/ This corresponds to `srWindow`.

defs.name: SmallRect
defs.docs: Defines the coordinates of the upper left and lower right corners of a rectangle.

attributes.value: / Defines the coordinates of the upper left and lower right corners of a rectangle.
/ This corresponds to [`SMALL_RECT`].
/ [`SMALL_RECT`]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/console/small-rect-str

defs.name: Console
defs.docs: A Windows console.

attributes.value: / A Windows console.
/ This represents a very limited set of functionality available to a Windows
/ console. In particular, it can only change text attributes such as color
/ and intensity. This may grow over time. If you need more routines, please
/ file an issue and/or PR.
/ There is no way to "write" to this console. Simply write to
/ stdout or stderr instead, while interleaving instructions to the console
/ to change text attributes.
/ A common pitfall when using a console is to forget to flush writes to
/ stdout before setting new text attributes.
/ # Example
/ ```no_run
/ # #[cfg(windows)]
/ use winapi_util::console::{Console, Color, Intense};
/ let mut con = Console::stdout().unwrap();
/ con.fg(Intense::Yes, Color::Cyan).unwrap();
/ println!("This text will be intense cyan.");
/ con.reset().unwrap();
/ println!("This text will be normal.");

defs.name: stdout
defs.docs: Create a new Console to stdout.

attributes.value: / Create a new Console to stdout.
/ If there was a problem creating the console, then an error is returned.

defs.name: stderr
defs.docs: Create a new Console to stderr.

attributes.value: / Create a new Console to stderr.
/ If there was a problem creating the console, then an error is returned.

defs.name: fg
defs.value: pub fn fg(&mut Self, Intense, Color) -> io::Result<()>
defs.docs:
Apply the given intensity and color attributes to the console
 foreground.

attributes.value: / Apply the given intensity and color attributes to the console
/ foreground.
/ If there was a problem setting attributes on the console, then an error
/ is returned.

defs.name: bg
defs.value: pub fn bg(&mut Self, Intense, Color) -> io::Result<()>
defs.docs:
Apply the given intensity and color attributes to the console
 background.

attributes.value: / Apply the given intensity and color attributes to the console
/ background.
/ If there was a problem setting attributes on the console, then an error
/ is returned.

defs.name: reset
defs.docs: Reset the console text attributes to their original settings.

attributes.value: / Reset the console text attributes to their original settings.
/ The original settings correspond to the text attributes on the console
/ when this `Console` value was created.
/ If there was a problem setting attributes on the console, then an error
/ is returned.

defs.name: set_virtual_terminal_processing
defs.value: pub fn set_virtual_terminal_processing(&mut Self, bool) -> io::Result<()>
defs.docs: Toggle virtual terminal processing.

attributes.value: / Toggle virtual terminal processing.
/ This method attempts to toggle virtual terminal processing for this
/ console. If there was a problem toggling it, then an error returned.
/ On success, the caller may assume that toggling it was successful.
/ When virtual terminal processing is enabled, characters emitted to the
/ console are parsed for VT100 and similar control character sequences
/ that control color and other similar operations.

defs.name: Intense
defs.docs: Whether to use intense colors or not.

attributes.value: / Whether to use intense colors or not.
allow(missing_docs)

defs.name: Color
defs.value: pub enum Color { Black, Blue, Green, Red, Cyan, Magenta, Yellow, White, }
defs.docs: The set of available colors for use with a Windows console.

attributes.value: / The set of available colors for use with a Windows console.
allow(missing_docs)

defs.name: file
defs.docs: Safe routines for dealing with files and handles on Windows.

attributes.value: / Safe routines for dealing with files and handles on Windows.
cfg(windows)

defs.name: information
defs.docs: Return various pieces of information about a file.

attributes.value: / Return various pieces of information about a file.
/ This includes information such as a file's size, unique identifier and
/ time related fields.
/ This corresponds to calling [`GetFileInformationByHandle`].
/ [`GetFileInformationByHandle`]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/api/fileapi/nf-fileapi-getfileinformationbyhandle

defs.name: typ
defs.docs: Returns the file type of the given handle.

attributes.value: / Returns the file type of the given handle.
/ If there was a problem querying the file type, then an error is returned.
/ This corresponds to calling [`GetFileType`].
/ [`GetFileType`]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/api/fileapi/nf-fileapi-getfiletype

defs.name: is_hidden
defs.docs:
Returns true if and only if the given file attributes contain the
 `FILE_ATTRIBUTE_HIDDEN` attribute.

attributes.value: / Returns true if and only if the given file attributes contain the
/ `FILE_ATTRIBUTE_HIDDEN` attribute.

defs.docs: Represents file information such as creation time, file size, etc.

attributes.value: / Returns file attributes.

defs.name: is_hidden
defs.docs:
Returns true if and only if this file information has the
 `FILE_ATTRIBUTE_HIDDEN` attribute.

attributes.value: / Returns true if and only if this file information has the

defs.docs: Return the creation time, if one exists.

attributes.value: / Return the creation time, if one exists.

defs.docs: Return the serial number of the volume that the file is on.

attributes.value: / Return the serial number of the volume that the file is on.

defs.name: file_size
defs.docs: Return the file size, in bytes.

attributes.value: / Return the file size, in bytes.

defs.docs: Return the number of links to this file.

attributes.value: / Return the number of links to this file.

defs.name: file_index
defs.docs:
Return the index of this file. The index of a file is a purpotedly
 unique identifier for a file within a particular volume.

attributes.value: / Return the index of this file. The index of a file is a purpotedly
/ unique identifier for a file within a particular volume.

defs.name: Type
defs.docs: Represents a Windows file type.

attributes.value: / Represents a Windows file type.
/ This wraps the result of [`GetFileType`].
/ [`GetFileType`]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/api/fileapi/nf-fileapi-getfiletype

defs.name: is_char
defs.docs:
Returns true if this type represents a character file, which is
 typically an LPT device or a console.

attributes.value: / Returns true if this type represents a character file, which is
/ typically an LPT device or a console.

defs.name: is_disk
defs.docs: Returns true if this type represents a disk file.

attributes.value: / Returns true if this type represents a disk file.

defs.name: is_pipe
defs.docs:
Returns true if this type represents a sock, named pipe or an
 anonymous pipe.

attributes.value: / Returns true if this type represents a sock, named pipe or an
/ anonymous pipe.

defs.name: is_unknown
defs.docs: Returns true if this type is not known.

attributes.value: / Returns true if this type is not known.
/ Note that this never corresponds to a failure.

defs.name: Handle
defs.docs:
A handle represents an owned and valid Windows handle to a file-like
 object.

attributes.value: / A handle represents an owned and valid Windows handle to a file-like
/ object.
/ When an owned handle is dropped, then the underlying raw handle is closed.
/ To get a borrowed handle, use `HandleRef`.

defs.name: from_file
defs.docs: Create an owned handle to the given file.

attributes.value: / Create an owned handle to the given file.
/ When the returned handle is dropped, the file is closed.
/ Note that if the given file represents a handle to a directory, then
/ it is generally required that it have been opened with the
/ [`FILE_FLAG_BACKUP_SEMANTICS`] flag in order to use it in various
/ calls such as `information` or `typ`. To have this done automatically
/ for you, use the `from_path_any` constructor.
/ [`FILE_FLAG_BACKUP_SEMANTICS`]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/api/FileAPI/nf-fileapi-createfilea

defs.name: from_path
defs.docs:
Open a file to the given file path, and return an owned handle to that
 file.

attributes.value: / Open a file to the given file path, and return an owned handle to that
/ file.
/ When the returned handle is dropped, the file is closed.
/ If there was a problem opening the file, then the corresponding error
/ is returned.

defs.name: from_path_any
defs.docs: Like `from_path`, but supports opening directory handles as well.

attributes.value: / Like `from_path`, but supports opening directory handles as well.
/ If you use `from_path` on a directory, then subsequent queries using
/ that handle will fail.

defs.name: as_file
defs.docs: Return this handle as a standard `File` reference.

attributes.value: / Return this handle as a standard `File` reference.

defs.name: as_file_mut
defs.docs: Return this handle as a standard `File` mutable reference.

attributes.value: / Return this handle as a standard `File` mutable reference.

defs.name: HandleRef
defs.docs:
Represents a borrowed and valid Windows handle to a file-like object, such
 as stdin/stdout/stderr or an actual file.

attributes.value: / Represents a borrowed and valid Windows handle to a file-like object, such
/ as stdin/stdout/stderr or an actual file.
/ When a borrowed handle is dropped, then the underlying raw handle is
/ **not** closed. To get an owned handle, use `Handle`.

defs.name: stdin
defs.docs: Create a borrowed handle to stdin.

attributes.value: / Create a borrowed handle to stdin.
/ When the returned handle is dropped, stdin is not closed.

defs.name: stdout
defs.docs: Create a handle to stdout.

attributes.value: / Create a handle to stdout.
/ When the returned handle is dropped, stdout is not closed.

defs.name: stderr
defs.docs: Create a handle to stderr.

attributes.value: / Create a handle to stderr.
/ When the returned handle is dropped, stderr is not closed.

defs.name: from_file
defs.docs: Create a borrowed handle to the given file.

attributes.value: / Create a borrowed handle to the given file.
/ When the returned handle is dropped, the file is not closed.

defs.name: from_raw_handle
defs.docs: Create a borrowed handle from the given raw handle.

attributes.value: / Create a borrowed handle from the given raw handle.
/ Note that unlike the `FromRawHandle` trait, this constructor does
/ **not** consume ownership of the given handle. That is, when the
/ borrowed handle created by this constructor is dropped, the underlying
/ handle will not be closed.
/ # Safety
/ This is unsafe because there is no guarantee that the given raw handle
/ is a valid handle. The caller must ensure this is true before invoking
/ this constructor.

defs.name: as_file
defs.docs: Return this handle as a standard `File` reference.

attributes.value: / Return this handle as a standard `File` reference.

defs.name: as_file_mut
defs.docs: Return this handle as a standard `File` mutable reference.

attributes.value: / Return this handle as a standard `File` mutable reference.

defs.name: AsHandleRef
defs.docs: Construct borrowed and valid Windows handles from file-like objects.

attributes.value: / Construct borrowed and valid Windows handles from file-like objects.

defs.name: as_handle_ref
defs.docs: A borrowed handle that wraps the raw handle of the `Self` object.

attributes.value: / A borrowed handle that wraps the raw handle of the `Self` object.

defs.name: as_raw
defs.docs:
A convenience routine for extracting a `HandleRef` from `Self`, and
 then extracting a raw handle from the `HandleRef`.

attributes.value: / A convenience routine for extracting a `HandleRef` from `Self`, and
/ then extracting a raw handle from the `HandleRef`.
